awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamics of Circular Macromolecules (DNA): From Single Molecules to Highly Entangled States
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  McKenna, Gregory B. / Schroeder, Charles / Anderson, Rae
Proposal Number:  1603943/ 1604038 / 1603925 

The goal of this proposal is to explore the behavior of polymer molecules that form large rings, instead of the usual linear polymer molecules. Such polymers, an example of which can be the DNA molecule, behave in a different way than linear molecules when processed or when they flow in a solution, because there are no ends in the chains. Results of this work can lead to improved polymer materials, to understanding in detail the behavior of bio-molecules, and to new technologies for DNA sequencing. 

Circular polymers are fascinating materials that have inspired polymer theorists and experimentalists for decades. The dynamics of circular chains differ fundamentally from their linear counterparts due to the absence of chain ends. Despite recent progress, however, the effects of circular topology on polymer dynamics remain a key unresolved problem in the field. In this proposal, the PIs are poised to make major progress in our understanding by preparing circular and linear DNA molecules that are monodisperse and of high topological purity. The assembled team has the expertise to synthesize and characterize circular and linear DNA, and will study the rheological behavior of these materials over a wider range of concentrations and molecular weights than previously achieved. A comprehensive approach is proposed that will include macroscopic and micro-rheology, single molecule polymer dynamics, and DNA synthesis, to provide new information regarding the dynamics of linear and circular DNA. Beyond providing a point of departure for understanding their circular counterparts, the parallel study of linear entangled DNA will provide unprecedented data using perfectly monodisperse DNA samples to directly test predictions from reptation theory, such as the cross-over to reptative behavior at extremely high entanglement densities. In addition to graduate student participation, educational activities are proposed in all three collaborating institutions, ranging from underrepresented minority student involvement at Texas Tech, to high school teacher engagement at Illinois and undergraduate student participation at the U of San Diego, a mainly undergraduate institution.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the dynamics of circular macromolecules and their mixtures with chains of linear topology remains an important challenge at both fundamental and applied levels of knowledge. The circular topology leads to challenges to our understanding of macromolecular interactions not only with similar molecules but also with simple linear macromolecules. The scientific challenges to our understanding of circular macromolecules and solutions to them form an important foundation for the rapidly emerging technologies related to the life sciences and polymer technologies. Thus, not only is it widely recognized that circular DNA is essential to fundamental life processes and emerging biotechnologies such as single cell DNA sequencing, it is also now known that a small amount of linear contaminant dramatically increases the viscosity and changes the dynamic response of the circular counterpart in the case of synthetic polymer melts. Yet, much of this knowledge has not advanced significantly since it was first discovered in the 1980s except that the amount of linear contaminant that is needed to modify the ring properties is now recognized to be less than a few percent.  The difficulty of fully understanding ring molecules created by conventional molecular synthesis methods is related not only to the issue of linear contaminants, but it is also related to the inability to make extremely large rings has been limited to molecular weights equivalent to fewer than 20 entanglements if the system were made of linear molecules. Thus, carrying out experiments on extremely large DNA molecules made using biological constructs provides an exciting means to overcome the synthetic polymer limitations.

In the current project, we have succeeded in growing bacterial cells and extracting circular DNA molecules with quantifiable amounts of linear chain content. The molecular weights of the circular DNA are either of 45 kbp (2.9x107 g/mol) or 4.6 Mbp (3x109 g/mol) as are the linear chains in the mixtures. We compare the responses with the behavior of a linear DNA obtained commercially (l-phage having a molecular weight of 47.5 kbp (3.1x107 g/mol)). The entanglement densities of the ring/linear mixtures based upon the known linear chain equivalent ranged from approximately 7 for the 45 kbp material at 0.8 mg/mL concentration to over 850 for the 4.6 Mbp material at a total DNA concentration of 1.2 mg/mL.  As shown in Figure 1 the dependence of the plateau modulus on total DNA concentration of the entangled systems is very similar independent of the amount of linear chain concentration in the mixtures.  At the same time, the absolute value of the plateau modulus depends strongly on the amount of linear chain present. This is seen in Figure 2 where the value of the plateau modulus normalized to that of the linear chain equivalent is plotted as a function of the linear concentration. Here the results are seen to be similar to early results on melts of ring and linear chains of much lower degree of nominal ring entanglement densities.  The results of both figures suggest strongly that the entanglement topology of the ring/linear mixtures is strongly related to the way in which the linear chains thread and entangle with the rings. Future work is required to establish the response of truly pure rings.


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Gregory B Mckenna

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Plateau modulus vs. total concentration of DNA in the aqueous buffer for different linear content samples compared with linear DNA.
    Gregory B. McKenna
    Copyrighted
    Gregory B Mckenna
    Plateau modulus vs. total DNA Concentration
  • Figure 2. Plateau modulus of ring/linear mixtures normalized by the modulus of the 100% linear material vs concentration of linear chains. Data are compared with literature data for synthetic polymer melts (PS=polystyrene; PBD=polybutadiene).
    Gregory B. McKenna
    Copyrighted
    Gregory B Mckenna
    Plateau modulus vs concentration of linear chains
